Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: OLC/SDSU/SDSMT Pre-Engineering Education Collaborative

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Oglala Lakota College (OLC) proposes to extend and enhance its capability to
deliver the first two years of a Bachelor of Science degree program in engineering. This
capability will be developed through a Pre-Engineering Education Collaborative (PEEC)
established with the College of Engineering at the South Dakota State University (SDSU) and the
South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSMT), and is referred to as the
OLC/SDSU/SDSMT PEEC (OSSPEEC). The project will establish collaborative offerings of
gateway and bottleneck courses that occur in the first two years of engineering curricula coupled
with on-reservation hands-on laboratory and service learning experiences on the PRR that will
increase Native American student retention in pre-engineering and engineering programs across
South Dakota. A major result of this project will be the establishment of a complete two-year pre-
engineering curriculum at OLC, which will enable our students to enter any four-year
undergraduate engineering program at the junior level. Further, this project will make an
additional unique or radical step in the transformation of classical engineering education at the
state colleges participating in the collaboration.
We propose to collaborate to develop and offer the courses required for an integrated two-year
pre-engineering program at OLC and to increase the success of OLC transfer and other Native
American students at SDSU and SDSMT through shared research, internship experiences, and
community building in the third and fourth years of an engineering program. The project will be
unique in the United States in that during the collaborative process of building OLCs pre-
engineering capacity, OLCs faculty and students will be helping to transform the concept of the
first two years of the engineering curriculum at SDSU and SDSMT. This will occur through the
integration of project based service learning and undergraduate research projects on the Pine
Ridge Reservation, which will involve professors and cohorts of students from SDSU and
SDSMT. Also, these projects will cultivate closer ties among our institutions and OST Tribal
Agencies through collaborative summer research and internship opportunities on the Pine Ridge
Reservation that will lead to the development of future collaborative NSF research proposals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the goal of bringing pre-engineering and engineering to Native American and Native Hawaiian students, the National Science Foundation funded what became known as the PEEC (Pre-Engineering Education Collaborative) program. Last year, Paul Boyer joined 33 other authors to tell the story of PEEC in book form. The PEEC project spanned four states: Hawaii, North Dakota, South Dakota and Wisconsin, and it included 17 colleges and universities. The seven-year, ongoing project included five Native Hawaiin serving community colleges and six Tribal Colleges, and each partnered with at least one of six mainstream universities. The resulting PEEC book, with editors from the South Dakota PEEC, brought together 34 advisory council members from 16 of the 17 PEEC institutions to provide guidance for the 34 authors. The editors and authors hope that readers of the book will gain insights to help foster the intent of the unique PEEC program long into the future, particularly including Tribal and Native colleges. The book has intellectual merit through leaving a lasting legacy of successes, challenges, best practices, recommendations, and hopes for the future, in order to share experiences for the benefit of practitioners of PEEC and for those with like interests at non-PEEC schools.

The South Dakota PEEC program is designed to provide undergraduate research experiences to Native American students at Oglala Lakota College (OLC), South Dakota School of Mines and Technology (SDSM&T), and South Dakota State University (SDSU) with an overall goal of encouraging Native American students to graduate from an engineering program at a mainstream university. Throughout the duration of this award, SDSM&T worked closely with OLC and SDSU to increase capacity at OLC, where they offer a pre-enigineering program based on constructivist teaching principles and design throughout the curriculum. This approach was unique in aligning engineering education with community relevant (tribal and native Hawaiian) hands-on projects as a vehicle for students to better understand engineering activities and principles. Research projects included in the South Dakota PEEC program are reservation based (on the Pine Ridge Reservation) and they are designed to provide experiential learning while at the same time addressing needs within the reservation community. Projects within the South Dakota PEEC program have included design and construction of a sustainable greenhouse, affordable housing designs, renewable energy sources, indoor air quality, and numerous hydrological and geological investigations. Students in the program present the results of their research at state-wide venues such as the NSF EPSCoR Student Research Symposium at the state capitol, and several have gone on to present at national venues such as the American Indian Science and Engineering Society (AISES) national conferences. A number of student participants in the South Dakota PEEC program have placed first, second, or third in student poster competitions, and two South Dakota PEEC student participants were awarded the presitigious Udall Scholar Award. A broader impact of this work is that culturally relevant, hands-on activities positively impacted the preparation and persistence of these pre-engineering and engineering students, especially those who are under-represented in STEM. Other broader impacts of PEEC are reflected in the number of Native American participants in the program who performed research, earned degrees and advanced degrees, wrote and published papers, and who continue to inspire others to follow in their footsteps. Specific broader impacts resulting from the South Dakota PEEC program include financial academic support for 59 student participants (including 24 from SDSM&T) resulting in 17 four-year baccalaureate degrees and 12 two-year associate degrees in STEM curricula, and many student participants are still working on their degree programs. Twenty-five of the students in the program were female, and 14 were graduate students. The program also trains and advances the educational capacity of instructors at OLC which affects all of the students in the OLC Math and Science Department. Eight additional gateway and bottleneck STEM courses also were offered at OLC through the South Dakota PEEC program.

Intellectual merits of the South Dakota PEEC program include advances in knowledge and understanding of the efficacy of engineering education approaches for underrepresented minority groups such as Native Americans. Concepts such as "social capital" and vertically integrated constructivist learning theories are integrated into the program and can be evaluated for use in future Native American programs and for potential use with other underrepresented minority groups and in other fields of study. Results of individual project based experiential learning activities also advance knowledge on specific fileds of engineering research. To date, 23 publications have resulted from the South Dakota PEEC program.
